content:
Settings > General under Language & Appearance > Advanced This sets up what your 'Medium' view will be and you would need to set this up for whatever languages you use - eg: Latin and Other Writing Systems. This area also allows you to control the minimum size of font. Do not do anything in this area just yet as I need some information first to advise on what is required to get everything in balance.

  • Settings > Composition
  • under 'HTML Style' section

controls what is used in the Write message -composing window. It is advised that you set this as follows:

  • Font: Variable width
  • Size: Medium

Then it will use whatever is set up as medium for you meaning it will a suitable size for reading when creating a new mail, but it will not dictate the actual size which means the recipient will be able to read the emails as they prefer on their computer because they will not necessarilly have the same screen resolution or use the same font or have perfect eyesight.

  • Please make sure you have that setting.

In the Config Editor this setting will change the size of the pixels generically throughout Thunderbird in everything. So you may have a size of 14 pixel (note Thunderbird uses pixels not points), but if you alter the size of the pixel, it's like changing the resolution, so it's still a size 14 but now appears larger. layout.css.devPixelsPerPx The default setting is a negative number -1.0

But if you have got all the other settings not set up correctly then you will still get a variety of outcomes in various areas, so let's start by setting the layout.css.devPixelsPerPx back to default. Please set layout.css.devPixelsPerPx to -1.0

Then post the following information so I can what is going on in all the various options you have set up.

  • Help > More TRoubleshooting Information
  • Scroll down to 'Important Modified Preferences' section
  • Look for where it first mentions 'font.'
  • Copy ALL the occurances where it mentions 'font' at the start.
  • Paste them into this forum question.

content:
If you are using a VPN then switch it off. If you are using a program that uses 'localhost' eg: Apache then switch it off whilst trying to set up gmail account. In Firewall, make sure thunderbird.exe (program) is set up as an allowed program.

In gmail webmail account accessed via a browser, please make sure account is set up as Imap enabled. If you have set up to use 2 step verification then switch it off so you can set up using oauth2.

In Thunderbird Check javascript is enabled:

  • Settings > General
  • Scroll to bottom and click on 'Config Editor'
  • In search type: javascript
  • check: javascript.enabled = true

In Thunderbird make sure cookies are enabled.

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Under 'Web Content' section
  • Select checkbox 'Accept cookies from sites'
  • Accept third party cookies: 'Always'
  • Keep until: 'they expire'
  • click on 'Exceptions'
  • set up 'https://accounts.google.com' as 'Allow'
  • click on 'Save Changes'

I'm assuming you have not got any gmail account set up but whilst in this area double check nothing is saved in the passwords.

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • under 'Passwords' section
  • click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • If you see any mention of the gmail account, select each line and click on Remove.
  • New > Existing mail account
  • Enter name
  • Enter full gmail email address
  • Enter password - this is the same one you use to access webmail account
  • Select to remember password
  • Click on 'Continue'
  • Thunderbird will locate the server settings and by default will set up to use IMAP.

You should see: Incoming : IMAP

  • Server name: imap.gmail.com
  • Port: 993
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Oauth2
  • Username: full gmail email address

Outgoing SMTP

  • Server name: smtp.gmail.com
  • Port: 465
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Oauth2
  • Username: full gmail email address
  • So if you do not want IMAP then you will need to change the Incoming 'protocol' to POP3 option.
  • click on 'Done'

You should get a pop up with google asking to confirm it really is you. Enter gmail address and password to allow thunderbird access to server.

content:
If you are experiencing issues when trying to save a file directly to the Draft folder in Firefox and it's causing the browser to crash, there are a few steps you can take to troubleshoot the problem:

Clear browser cache and cookies: Clearing the cache and cookies can help resolve any temporary data conflicts that may be causing the issue. To do this, go to the Firefox menu, select "Options," go to the "Privacy & Security" section, and click on "Clear Data." Make sure to select both cache and cookies and then click "Clear."

Disable browser extensions: Browser extensions or add-ons can sometimes interfere with the normal functioning of Firefox. Try disabling all extensions and then attempt to save the file to the Draft folder again. If the issue is resolved, re-enable the extensions one by one to identify the specific one causing the problem.

content:
To transfer old emails from a Thunderbird POP account to a new Thunderbird Owl-EWS (Exchange Web Services) account, you can follow these steps:

Set up the Owl-EWS account in Thunderbird:

Open Thunderbird and go to "Tools" > "Account Settings." Click on "Account Actions" and select "Add Mail Account." Enter your name, email address, and password for the Owl-EWS account. Thunderbird will automatically configure the account using Owl-EWS settings. Enable the Owl-EWS account to access old POP emails:

In Thunderbird, go to "Tools" > "Account Settings." Select the Owl-EWS account from the left sidebar. Under the "Server Settings" tab, check the box that says "Allow immediate server notifications when new messages arrive." Click on "Advanced" and check the box that says "Include this server when getting new mail." Transfer emails from the POP account to the Owl-EWS account:

In Thunderbird, go to the POP account folder that contains the old emails you want to transfer. Select the emails you want to move by holding down the "Ctrl" key (or "Cmd" key on Mac) and clicking on each email. Right-click on the selected emails and choose "Move To" > "Owl-EWS account" > "Inbox" (or the desired folder in the Owl-EWS account). Thunderbird will start moving the selected emails to the Owl-EWS account.
